raid_types.name: No RAID
raid_types.description: No redundancy - all storage is usable
raid_types.notes: Not recommended for production - no fault tolerance

raid_types.name: RAID 0 (Striping)
raid_types.notes: High performance but no fault tolerance - data loss if any drive fails

raid_types.name: RAID 1 (Mirroring)
raid_types.notes: Good for small deployments requiring redundancy

raid_types.name: RAID 5 (Striping with Parity)
raid_types.description: Good balance of capacity and redundancy
raid_types.notes: Popular choice - can survive one drive failure. Calculation: (N-1)/N * 100

raid_types.name: RAID 6 (Dual Parity)
raid_types.description: Higher redundancy, can survive 2 drive failures

raid_types.name: RAID 10 (Mirrored Striping)
raid_types.notes: Excellent performance, recommended for high-throughput scenarios

raid_types.name: Nx Failover
raid_types.notes: Nx-specific failover - storage replicated to backup server

raid_types.name: Veracity
raid_types.notes: Nx-specific failover - storage replicated to backup server

filesystem_overhead.description: Additional 5% overhead for filesystem metadata and formatting

calculation_notes: Usable storage = Raw storage × (RAID usable percentage / 100) × (1 - filesystem overhead)
For RAID 5 with N drives: usable = (N-1)/N of raw capacity
For RAID 6 with N drives: usable = (N-2)/N of raw capacity
